definition: to take office/previous (incumbent)/predecessor
on top/upon/above/upper/previous/first (of multiple parts)/to climb/to get onto/to go up/to attend (class or university)
see 上聲|上声[shang3 sheng1]
surname Ren/Ren County 任縣|任县[Ren2 Xian4] in Hebei

to assign/to appoint/to take up a post/office/responsibility/to let/to allow/to give free rein to/no matter (how, what etc)/classifier for terms served in office, or for spouses, girlfriends etc (as in 前任男友)
to ride to take up an official appointment (idiom); to take on a job with alacrity/to undertake a task
(of a newly appointed official) to make bold changes on assuming office (idiom)
pinyin: xin1 guan1 shang4 ren4 san1 ba3 huo3

sentences.english: On the day Xie An assumed office, many officials came to congratulate him.
sentences.chinese: 谢安上任的那一天，很多官员都来祝贺。

sentences.english: Director Zhang solved an intricate case soon after he took his post.
sentences.chinese: 局长刚上任不久就将一件无头案侦破了。

sentences.english: Every mayor who takes office will repair a road, support a bridge.
sentences.chinese: 每上任一个市长就要修一次路，架一座桥。

sentences.english: He brought the company a good omen of a lot of money when he took over the position.
sentences.chinese: 他刚一上任就为公司带来了钱谷广进的好彩头。

sentences.english: I think a new broom sweeping clean is needed.
sentences.chinese: 经过多年腐败，我想新官上任需要新人和新的概念。

sentences.english: He came to office only six weeks ago, offering hope.
sentences.chinese: 6周以前，他深孚众望，走马上任。

sentences.english: The elections were over and the first native Governor was inaugurated.
sentences.chinese: 选举结束，第一个在当地土生土长的州长走马上任了。

sentences.english: Daintry'the brigadier explained'is our new broom . '
sentences.chinese: “邓粹是新官上任三把火，”旅长解释道。

sentences.english: The sales manager recently in power itched to hxdye a go at the East Asian market.
sentences.chinese: 新上任的销售经理跃跃欲试，要进军东亚市场。

sentences.english: Does your weight affect chances of you landing that next job?
sentences.chinese: 体重会不会影响你能否在一个新的领域里走马上任呢？

sentences.english: At first the new jp attends court as an observer.
sentences.chinese: 起初，那位新上任的治安官以观察员的身份出庭。

sentences.english: I saw the newly appointed Zuoshu Chang was there waiting for it.
sentences.chinese: 只见新上任的左庶长正在那里等着呢。

sentences.english: A new broom sweeps clean Lately, the gym has a "new" trainer manager, who is promoted from one of the trainers.
sentences.chinese: 新官上任三把火最近健身房里的教练换了一个经理。

sentences.english: Five months after his appointment a huge earthquake struck, leading to Haiti's worst medical emergency.
sentences.chinese: 上任刚满五个月，一场始未料及的地震突袭海地。

sentences.english: President Donald Trump has signed many documents in his first week in office.
sentences.chinese: 川普总统上任首周签署了很多文件。

sentences.english: But a crisis took office, as if someone was in preventing the continue to conduct.
sentences.chinese: 但是一上任便危机四伏，似乎有人在阻止查案的继续。

definition: to ride to take up an official appointment (idiom); to take on a job with alacrity/to undertake a task
to leave office/to leave one's post
to take over (as minister, manager etc)
newly-appointed/newly elected/new (in a political office)
to take office/to assume a post
to leave office
to take over (duties etc)/catcher (baseball etc)
to take up a post/to start in a new job
(of a newly appointed official) to make bold changes on assuming office (idiom)
pinyin: xin1 guan1 shang4 ren4 san1 ba3 huo3

definition: to wield (power etc)
to remain in office/to hold on to one's job
to travel to take up a new post
to be promoted to
successor
to replace/to take over (a position or post)
to fire/to sack/to dismiss/to terminate employment
